title: Lesson 4 - Working with Code and Artifacts
description: Learn to work with Claude's code artifacts: understanding what's generated, running code locally, making modifications, and building runnable projects without deep programming knowledge.
learningObjectives: Understand what artifacts are and how to use them effectively
Set up a basic local environment to run Claude-generated code
Read and modify code artifacts without deep programming knowledge
Test and troubleshoot Claude-generated code independently

videos.title: Artifacts Explained: Your Code Workspace
videos.description: What artifacts are, how they work, and how to think about code Claude generates for you.
scriptOutline: What are artifacts? (Separate panel for code, documents, diagrams)
How artifacts differ from regular text responses
Types of artifacts: code, React components, documents, SVGs, Mermaid diagrams
Live demo: generating a simple HTML artifact and opening it
talkingPoints: Artifacts are Claude's way of giving you 'finished products' — ready-to-use files
You don't need to understand every line — you need to know how to use it
Think of artifacts like IKEA furniture: Claude gives you the parts, you assemble
Artifacts are versioned — Claude updates them when you ask for changes

videos.title: Setting Up Your Dev Environment (The Minimum)
videos.description: What tools you actually need to run code locally — no fancy IDE required.
scriptOutline: The minimum setup: text editor (VS Code) + terminal + browser
Installing Node.js for running modern web projects
Running Claude's code: npm run dev, opening localhost
When you don't need setup: HTML files, simple scripts
Live demo: running a Next.js project Claude generated
talkingPoints: You don't need to be a developer to run code — just follow the recipe
VS Code is free, beginner-friendly, and handles most projects
npm install is like 'download the dependencies' — always run it first
localhost:3000 means 'your computer is hosting a website, only you can see it'
If something doesn't work, the error message tells you what's missing

videos.title: Reading Code for Non-Programmers
videos.description: How to navigate code files, understand structure, and make simple changes without breaking things.
scriptOutline: File structure: what src/, components/, pages/ mean
Reading code top-to-bottom: imports → logic → exports
What you can safely change: text, colors, numbers, URLs
What NOT to change: syntax, brackets, imports (unless Claude tells you)
Using Claude to explain specific parts: 'What does this function do?'
Live demo: changing text and colors in a React component
talkingPoints: Code is just text — you can't 'break' it permanently, you can always undo
Focus on what's in quotes — that's usually content you can edit
Numbers often control size, spacing, timing — experiment safely
When in doubt, ask Claude: 'How do I change X in this code?'
Save before every change, test after every change

textSections.title: Types of Artifacts and When to Use Each
textSections.content:
**1. CODE (HTML/JavaScript/React)**
Best for: Interactive web pages, apps, UIs
How to use: Save as .html or follow Claude's setup instructions
Example prompt: 'Create an interactive todo list I can run in my browser'

**2. REACT COMPONENT**
Best for: Reusable UI pieces for web apps
How to use: Copy into your React project's components folder
Example prompt: 'Create a signup form component with email validation'

**3. DOCUMENT (Markdown)**
Best for: Documentation, guides, content
How to use: Copy to a .md file or use as-is
Example prompt: 'Create a README for my project'

**4. DIAGRAM (SVG/Mermaid)**
Best for: Flowcharts, architecture diagrams, visualizations
How to use: Download SVG or render Mermaid in a viewer
Example prompt: 'Create a flowchart for my user onboarding process'

**5. TEXT/SCRIPTS**
Best for: Utilities, configurations, data files
How to use: Save with appropriate extension (.json, .sh, .py)
Example prompt: 'Create a script to rename all my image files'

**Choosing:**
- Want something interactive? → Code/React
- Want to document? → Document
- Want to visualize? → Diagram
- Want to automate? → Script

textSections.title: The Basic Dev Environment Checklist
textSections.content:
**Essential Tools (one-time setup):**

1. **Text Editor: VS Code**
   - Download: https://code.visualstudio.com/
   - Why: Free, beginner-friendly, works for any language
   - Install extensions: Prettier (auto-format), ESLint (catch errors)

2. **Node.js + npm**
   - Download: https://nodejs.org/ (get LTS version)
   - Why: Runs modern JavaScript projects
   - Test install: Open terminal, type `node -v`

3. **Web Browser**
   - Chrome or Firefox (you probably already have this)
   - Why: See your projects running

4. **Terminal/Command Line**
   - Mac: Built-in Terminal app
   - Windows: Command Prompt or PowerShell
   - Why: Run commands Claude gives you

**Optional but Helpful:**
- Git (for version control): https://git-scm.com/
- GitHub Desktop (easier Git): https://desktop.github.com/

**That's it!** You don't need XCode, Android Studio, or fancy IDEs.

**First-Time Setup Workflow:**
1. Install VS Code
2. Install Node.js
3. Open VS Code terminal (View → Terminal)
4. You're ready to run Claude's code!

textSections.title: Running Claude's Code: Step-by-Step
textSections.content:
**For Simple HTML Files:**
1. Copy Claude's code
2. Paste into a new file, save as `index.html`
3. Double-click the file → opens in browser
4. Done!

**For Node.js/React Projects:**
1. Copy all of Claude's code into appropriately named files
2. Open terminal in the project folder
3. Run: `npm install` (downloads dependencies)
   - Wait for it to finish (can take 1-2 minutes)
4. Run: `npm run dev` (or `npm start`, Claude will tell you)
5. Open browser to `http://localhost:3000`
6. See your app running!

**Making Changes:**
1. Edit the file in VS Code
2. Save (Cmd+S / Ctrl+S)
3. Refresh browser (most modern setups auto-refresh)
4. See changes immediately

**If Something Breaks:**
1. Check terminal for error messages
2. Copy the full error
3. Ask Claude: 'I got this error: [paste error]. How do I fix it?'
4. Apply Claude's fix
5. Try again

**Pro tip:** Keep the terminal open while developing. Errors appear there first.

textSections.title: What You Can Safely Change in Code
textSections.content:
**✅ SAFE TO EDIT:** **Text in Quotes:** ```javascript

"Welcome!"

// Change to "Hello!" const message = "Hi there" // Change to any text ``` **Numbers (spacing, sizes, delays):** ```javascript width: 300 // Try 400, 500, etc. setTimeout(() => {}, 1000) // 1000 = 1 second, try 2000 padding: 20px // Try 10px, 30px ``` **Colors (hex codes or names):** ```javascript background: "#3498db" // Try "#e74c3c" or "blue" color: "white" // Try "black", "red", etc. ``` **URLs and Paths:** ```javascript fetch("https://api.example.com") // Change to your API image src="/logo.png" // Change to your image path ``` **Boolean flags (true/false):** ```javascript const isVisible = true // Try false // Try true ``` **⚠️ BE CAREFUL WITH:** **Brackets and Syntax:** ```javascript function doThing() { // Don't delete { or } return "value" // Don't forget closing } } ``` **Imports:** ```javascript import React from 'react' // Don't edit unless you know why ``` **Variable Names:** Changing `userName` to `name` might break other code that references it. **When in doubt:** 'Claude, how do I change [X] in this code?' → Safer than guessing!

textSections.title: Troubleshooting Common Issues
textSections.content:
**Error: 'node' is not recognized**
→ Node.js not installed or not in PATH
→ Fix: Install Node.js, restart terminal

**Error: 'npm install' fails**
→ Network issue or permission problem
→ Fix: Try `npm install --force` or check internet connection

**Error: Port 3000 already in use**
→ Another app is using that port
→ Fix: Stop other dev servers, or use a different port with `PORT=3001 npm run dev`

**Error: Module not found**
→ Missing dependency
→ Fix: Run `npm install [missing-module]`

**Error: Syntax error in browser**
→ Code has a typo or bracket mismatch
→ Fix: Check VS Code for red squiggly lines, or ask Claude to review

**Nothing appears in browser**
→ Check terminal for errors
→ Check browser console (F12 → Console tab)
→ Make sure you're on the right URL (localhost:3000)

**Changes don't appear**
→ Hard refresh: Cmd+Shift+R (Mac) or Ctrl+Shift+R (Windows)
→ Check if file is saved (dot on VS Code tab means unsaved)

**General debugging process:**
1. Read the error message fully
2. Google '[error message] + [technology]' (e.g., 'module not found react')
3. Ask Claude with full error text
4. If still stuck, ask in community (Discord, Stack Overflow)

textSections.title: Key Definitions
textSections.content:
**Artifact:** A discrete output from Claude (code, document, diagram) shown in a separate panel

**Localhost:** A web address (http://localhost:3000) that means 'this computer' — only you can access it

**npm (Node Package Manager):** Tool for installing JavaScript libraries/dependencies

**Dependencies:** External code libraries your project needs to run

**Terminal/Command Line:** Text-based interface for running commands

**Package.json:** File listing your project's dependencies and scripts

**Source Code (src/):** The folder containing your app's main code

**Dev Server:** A local server that runs your project for testing

commonMistakes.explanation: Dependencies must be downloaded first. Always run npm install after getting new code.

commonMistakes.mistake: Editing code in the browser instead of VS Code
commonMistakes.explanation: Browser changes are temporary. Edit the actual files in VS Code, then refresh.

commonMistakes.mistake: Deleting brackets or quotes while changing text
commonMistakes.explanation: Keep the syntax intact. Only change what's inside quotes, not the quotes themselves.

commonMistakes.mistake: Not checking the terminal for errors
commonMistakes.explanation: Terminal shows errors first. If something breaks, look there before Googling.
If Claude says 'run X', ask 'What does this command do?' before running it.

reflectionQuestions: What feels more intimidating: writing code from scratch or modifying Claude's code? Why?
Think of a simple change you'd want to make to a website you use. Could you make that change in Claude's code?
How confident do you feel running terminal commands? What would help you feel more comfortable?

exercises.output: A running local project (screenshot of it in your browser at localhost:3000) plus documentation of setup steps you followed

exercises.title: Customize an Artifact
exercises.description: Take a Claude-generated artifact and make 5 meaningful changes without breaking it.
exercises.output: Before/after screenshots showing your changes, plus the modified code and a list of what you changed
successCriteria: Made at least 5 distinct changes (text, colors, sizes, etc.)
Changes are visible and intentional (not random)
Can explain what each change does
Tested after each change to catch breaks early

exercises.title: Debug and Fix
exercises.description: Intentionally break a working artifact, then use Claude to help you fix it.
exercises.output: Debug log showing: (1) What you broke, (2) Error message, (3) Prompt you used to ask Claude for help, (4) Claude's fix, (5) Proof it works again
successCriteria: Intentionally introduced a clear break (deleted a bracket, typo'd a variable, etc.)
Captured the full error message from terminal/browser
Asked Claude a good debugging question (included error + context)
Learned one lesson about what NOT to do

instructorNotes: This lesson is standalone — works even if students skipped earlier lessons. Quick recap of 'what is Claude?' may help.
For live sessions: Screen-share the full setup process. Students WILL have install issues — budget time for troubleshooting.
Common anxiety: 'I'll break something.' Emphasize: you can't break your computer, only the project, and Cmd+Z exists!
Self-paced tip: Create a #setup-help channel in Discord where students post error messages. Community often solves faster than instructor.
Time check: Exercise 1 can take 90+ minutes if students hit Node.js install issues on Windows. Consider making this async homework.
Bonus: Create a 'gallery' of customized artifacts students make in Exercise 2. Shows creativity and removes fear.
Platform note: Mac vs. Windows commands differ (terminal vs. PowerShell). Provide both in examples.
Key mindset shift: You're not learning to code, you're learning to USE code Claude generates. Big difference!
